awd_titl_txt: Quantum Phases, Interactions and Topology of Dressed BECs
awd_abstract_narration:
When a gas of atoms is cooled to a temperature close to absolute zero, it exhibits unusual behavior described by the theory of quantum mechanics. According to this theory, atoms have both a particle-like and a wave-like nature at the same time, which gives rise to behaviors that do not seem intuitive based on ordinary experience in everyday life. This project consists of a line of research using tailored laser and radio-frequency fields to investigate inherently quantum mechanical phenomena including unusual states of matter, the role of interatomic interactions in precision measurement schemes, and a new paradigm for modelling general quantum systems using ultracold atoms. This project will promote the progress of science and technology by providing insight into intricate quantum mechanical effects in a well-controlled environment that involves quantum complexities while remaining simple enough to be amenable to the development of new mathematical descriptions. Since quantum mechanical behavior becomes dominant not only in the realm of ultracold temperatures but also in the realm of very small dimensions, the knowledge acquired through this project will also provide impetus for the development of next generation nanoelectronics devices, for precision measurement or for quantum information.  
 
This project uses dilute-gas Bose-Einstein condensates formed by cooling rubidium atoms to temperatures near zero Kelvin. The atoms in the condensate form a macroscopic quantum system that can be manipulated and probed in very flexible ways. The project consists of a series of steps: First, by employing a suitably tailored light field comprised of the superposition of a Raman coupling field and an optical lattice, the excitation spectrum of a supersolid-like state will be studied that the Principal Investigator has recently realized in the lab. Second, a set of precision measurements will investigate the role of interaction effects in Raman dressing schemes and radio-frequency coupling schemes within the context of atom interferometry. This will illuminate the importance of interactions for quantum analog simulations. A clear cut demonstration of these interaction effects will be provided in the context of a spin tensor-momentum coupling scheme that leads to a variety of novel quantum phases. Finally, a new paradigm for quantum analog simulation will be experimentally realized by exploiting the parameter space of coupled internal states. This method has the potential to realize topological monopoles, enhancing our insight into advanced quantum mechanical concepts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project has been to use ultracold atoms to study exotic aspects of fundamental physics, in particular quantum mechanical behavior. The project has provided new fundamental insights into quantum mechanics and has opened up new avenues for experimentation. Quantum mechanics describes the fundamental behavior of nature on small scales, such as atomic scales. The underlying principles differ significantly from our everyday experiences. For example, particles start behaving as waves, and processes can exhibit fundamental uncertainty. This offers many new possibilities for applications ranging from ultrasensitive sensors to new paradigms of computing. Harnessing the unusual properties of quantum matter for such applications offers a technological leap forward but requires a detailed understanding of quantum mechanics, its connections to classical mechanics, and the ways in which we can manipulate quantum matter.

Through our experiments, we have probed quantum matter in new regimes. We use laser cooling and related techniques to confine a cloud of atoms inside a vacuum chamber and cool it to temperatures near absolute zero. At these temperatures, the atoms exhibit clear wave-like behavior and form large matter waves, known as Bose-Einstein condensates. These resulting clouds behave purely quantum mechanically and, remarkably, are large enough to be imaged directly with a custom microscope, providing direct experimental access to the quantum world. The behavior of the atoms can be further manipulated by embedding them in a bath of radiation fields, including  laser beams, radiofrequency, and microwave fields.

As significant results, we have explored these systems to investigate a diverse range of topics. Utilizing these systems, we have been able to experimentally model central aspects of condensed matter physics, such as spin-orbit coupling, supersolid-like phases of matter, and emergent lattice structures with exotic band structures. We have experimentally realized a new testbed to study Josephson junctions, which, when realized with superconductors, are central building blocks for quantum computers. We have studied fundamental aspects of nonlinear science evoked by interatomic interactions and have elucidated peculiar properties of the hydrodynamics of quantum systems, contrasting the flow of classical particles studied in classical hydrodynamics. The results of this project have been published in a series of top-tier journals, presented in invited and contributed talks and posters at national and international conferences, and have formed the foundation for a PhD thesis.

The project has significantly contributed to the education and mentoring of students at all levels. Participants have included a high school student, REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) students, visiting students from a primarily undergraduate institution, undergraduate students, and graduate students. The work on this project has provided students with first-hand experience in quantum technologies and has prepared them for careers in industry and academia alike. Graduates from our group have gone on to highly successful careers in optics industries, data science, national labs, and academia. The expertise gained within the frame of this project has also motivated advances of teaching activities at Washington State University, such as new undergraduate teaching lab experiments and new elements for an undergraduate quantum mechanics course. This work has been embedded in multiple collaborations with national and international theorists, forming a highly effective quantum network of researchers and providing ample opportunities for students to engage in discussions about their results, to network, broaden their horizons, and explore future career opportunities.
